Award.AwardTitle: Scaling K-12 Computer Science In Large Urban Districts: A Leadership Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computing has become an integral part of everyday practice within modern fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. As a result, the STEM+Computing Partnerships (STEM+C) program seeks to advance new multidisciplinary approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning, and discipline-specific efforts in computing designed to build an evidence base for teaching and learning of computer science in K-12, including within diverse populations. This project addresses that mission by convening a leadership conference for representatives of large urban school districts associated with the Council of Great City Schools. Each two-person team will include the district's Chief Academic Officer and a lead STEM educator. The one-day conference will: a) focus on the importance of computer science education in urban contexts; b) familiarize participants with a variety of planning tools to design and implement computer science programs; c) provide examples of current computer science initiatives; and d) promote participant networks to enable ongoing collaboration after the conference. During the conference, attendees will hear from and interact with representatives of major computer science curriculum efforts, successful leaders of large-scale STEM education efforts, computer scientists and computer science teachers, and scholars with expertise in standards-based reform efforts in large urban schools. The intent of the conference is to promote increased, targeted attention to the quality and quantity of computer science education within large urban schools with highly diverse student populations.

The computer science leadership conference will be held in conjunction with the 60th Annual Council of Great City Schools Fall Conference. Participant teams will be recruited from the 67 school districts comprising the Council and serving over 7 million diverse learners. A pre-conference survey will solicit participant information regarding current school district computer science efforts and challenges, and a survey will be administered at the conclusion of the conference to gain feedback about the effectiveness of the conference in raising awareness of needs, issues, resources, and implementation strategies related to school computer science programs. The success of the conference will be evaluated on the basis of results from these surveys, observations during conference sessions, and a review of conference artifacts distributed during the event. The collected data will be used to assess the extent to which conference participants indicate: a) a greater awareness of the current state of computer science education programs in K-12 schools; b) an increased knowledge of computer science improvement strategies for school districts; and c) willingness to interact with each other and other stakeholders after the conference to facilitate the development of a wide-scale infrastructure supporting computer science education in schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scaling K-12 Computer Science In Large Urban Districts: A Leadership Conference

Project Outcomes

NSF award 1542965 “Scaling K-12 Computer Science In Large Urban Districts: A Leadership Conference” to the University of Chicago provided resources to convene a conference for district administrators from large urban K-12 school districts to learn more about advancing K-12 computer science education efforts.

Our conference was held on October 18, 2016 in Miami, FL, immediately preceding the annual conference of the Council of the Great City Schools. There were 95 attendees at the conference, and 75% of the attendees were mid-level or senior-level administrators from large urban school districts. The vast majority of attendees indicated that the conference increased their knowledge about K-12 computer science instruction and policy, provided useful resources, and was a good use of time.

The conference began the night before with an informal meet-and-greet event for attendees who arrived to Miami early. After some early morning introductions, attendees heard about the need for computer science education from representatives from Oracle Corporation and the White House. Then, a team from the University of Chicago shared some findings about the current state of K-12 computer science in large urban districts, highlighting the various goals and strategies used by districts in the Council of the Great City Schools. A panel with administrators from Dallas Independent, San Francisco Unified, and Baltimore County School Districts responded to the report.

A keynote presentation from David Coleman of the College Board described the new Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles exam, and explained how this effort was designed to address some of the long-standing equity issues associated with teaching, learning, and leading computer science at the K-12 level. A series of “speed dating” sessions followed, where participants met with representatives of curriculum publishers, professional development providers, and tool-makers to understand how various services and partnerships might aid their districts. The conference concluded with representatives from the National Science Teachers Association, the National Council for the Teachers of Mathematics, the Computer Science Teachers Association, and the National Council of Supervisors of Mathematics, exploring how computer science connects to their disciplines.

After the conference concluded, materials were distributed to all participants, and three webinars we held that dug more deeply into the goals and strategies employed by large urban districts to improve computer science teaching, learning, and leading.

Intellectual Merit

There was considerable intellectual merit behind this conference. Improving the teaching, learning, and leading of computer science education is a national priority. This improvement will occur within school districts, and leadership and organization matter for school improvement. Urban districts represent a sizable proportion of students in the United States, particularly those of color. And tools and supports for those leaders in computer science education are limited. Therefore, efforts to increase communication, collaboration, and capacity within and among urban districts—such as via this conference—are essential.

Broader Impacts

The computer science education field is engaging in unprecedented efforts to generate a wide- scale infrastructure for high school CS education. Of the approximately 49.8 million students in public elementary and secondary schools (National Center for Education Statistics, 2014), approximately 7.1 million children (or 14%) are served by the medium and large urban districts that make up the Council of Great City Schools (Council of Great City Schools, 2015). Of these students, 81% are non-white and 68% are eligible to receive free or reduced-price lunch (Council of Great City Schools, 2015). Moreover, the majority of African-Americans and Latinos live in urban areas (Ennis et al., 2011; Rastogi et al., 2011). Success efforts to both increase the quality and quality of computer science education programs, particularly to students who are poor and non-white, will depend on the efforts of urban district leaders.
